1.title: Introduction to Basic 3D Primitives
1.content:
Most simple objects can be broken down into basic 3d primitives or 2d profiles that follow a line. These basic 3d primitives are most often:


  • Cylinders (soda can)

  • Rectangular Prisms (box)


When combined, these shapes can represent objects like a 9 volt battery


  • The cylinder is indicated by the purple arrow
  • The rectangular prism is indicated by the green bounding box

2.title: Less Common Primitives
2.content:
Less often, basic primitives can be:


  • Toruses (doughnut, shown in green)

  • Cones (funnel, shown in red)

  • Wedges (ramp, shown in blue)

  • Sphere (ball, shown in grey)


Notice: These primitives may be cut to form halves, quarters, or any subdivision

3.title: 3D to 2D Correlation
3.content:
Basic primitives can be broken down into 2 dimensional shapes that flow along a line or revolve about a line. For example:


  • A square along a line normal to it (Cube)






  • A triangle that is rotated about one of its legs (Cone)






  • A half circle rotated about it's straight edge (Sphere)

4.title: Shapes That Vary Along 2 Axes
4.content:
Certain 3d shapes vary along two different axis, such as a spring, which consists of a 2d profile (a circle) along a 3 dimensional line (a helix). Objects like these are a natural progression of the basic 3D primitives since they vary in two dimensions rather than 1.


  • Notice a 2D profile rotated about an axis not intersecting itself (a Torus) can equivalently be described as a 2D profile (a circle) following a path (a second circle whose center is not within the 2d profile).



  • If this circular path were stretched along the axis normal to it, it would create a helix, and sweeping a 2d profile along this, like a circular profile, would create a spring.

5.title: Negative Space
5.content:
In addition to positive space, these primitives may also be used to create negative space. These negative space primitives are used to create hollow volumes. Examples of this include:


  • A pipe: a cylinder with a second negative space cylinder inside


  • A basketball: a positive space sphere with a smaller negative space sphere inside


  • A bicycle inner tube: a torus with a smaller negative space torus inside


  • A hole in a piece of wood: a rectangular prism with a negative space cylinder inside

6.title: Combining Similar Primitives
6.content:
Often these primitives come in pairs and can be combined to create more complex volumes. A common volume made using multiple cylinders is a medicine bottle. This is made using the following progression:


  1. A positive cylinder making the main body


  2. A negative smaller cylinder creating the cavity in the body


  3. A larger diameter positive cylinder creating the cap


  4. A smaller diameter negative space cylinder creating the inside of the cap

7.title: Combining Different Primitives
7.content:
Combining different types of basic primitives can yield more complex shapes that vary in all three dimensions. For example, a pill shape can be thought of as a cylinder with rounded ends. The model to the right is an example of this, it consists of:

  • A cylinder (red) making the main portion of the body


  • Two half circles (blue) capping the ends
